title: What is Oilahuasca
content: Oilahuasca is a theory that common culinary spices containing allylbenzenes can produce psychoactive effects when combined with strategic cytochrome P450 enzyme modulators. This is analogous to how ayahuasca uses MAO inhibitors to potentiate DMT. The term was coined by researcher Ron69. Key finding: allylbenzenes metabolize to tertiary aminopropiophenones (NOT amphetamines as originally theorized by Shulgin). CYP450 enzyme manipulation can dramatically enhance bioavailability and duration.

title: Ron69 Discovery of Oilahuasca
content: Ron69 is the pioneering researcher who coined the term 'Oilahuasca' and systematically investigated the pharmacological basis for psychoactive effects from culinary spices. His methodology: Started with nutmeg (myristicin) research, studied NCBI/PubMed databases, identified CYP450 enzyme involvement, cross-referenced herbs containing allylbenzenes AND modulating CYP450, developed activation theory analogous to ayahuasca's MAOI mechanism. Published findings on HerbPedia Wikidot.

title: Alexander Shulgin Ten Essential Oils
content: Dr. Alexander Shulgin (1925-2014), author of PiHKAL and TiHKAL, proposed that ten natural essential oils could be converted to psychoactive compounds through hepatic metabolism. The ten: Estragole→4-MA, Methyleugenol→3,4-DMA, Safrole→MDA, Myristicin→MMDA (key compound), Croweacin→MMDA-3a, Asaricin→MMDA-2, Elemicin→TMA, Asarone→TMA-2 (potent), Apiole→DMMDA (highly potent), Dillapiole→DMMDA-2 (highly potent). Shulgin demonstrated myristicin conversion to MMDA through rabbit liver study.

title: Critical Correction - Not Amphetamines
content: Modern research (1977-2024) corrects Shulgin's 1963 theory: allylbenzenes do NOT form amphetamines in vivo. They actually form TERTIARY AMINOPROPIOPHENONES (Mannich bases). Three types detected in animal urine: dimethylamines, piperidines, and pyrrolidines. Key difference: aminopropiophenones have a ketone (C=O) and tertiary amines (NR2), not primary amines like amphetamines. Different receptor binding profiles and pharmacokinetics.

title: Allylbenzene Metabolic Pathway
content: The verified three-step metabolic process: Step 1 - CYP450 oxidation (primarily CYP1A2) converts allylbenzene to 1'-hydroxyallylbenzene at the benzylic carbon. Step 2 - Further oxidation converts hydroxyl to ketone, forming 1'-oxo metabolite (phenyl vinyl ketone). Step 3 - Spontaneous Mannich reaction (NO enzyme required) condenses the ketone with endogenous amines (dimethylamine, piperidine, pyrrolidine) to form tertiary aminopropiophenones.

title: Myristicin CYP1A2 Mechanism-Based Inhibition
content: Research (PMID 26091900) shows myristicin is a mechanism-based (suicide) inhibitor of CYP1A2. The 3.21-fold IC50 shift indicates irreversible inhibition - the enzyme processes myristicin, generates a reactive intermediate (M2: 1'-hydroxymyristicin or 2',3'-epoxy-myristicin), which permanently destroys the enzyme. Glutathione can block this by trapping the reactive intermediate. Recovery requires 24-72 hours to synthesize new enzyme.

title: The Induction-Inhibition Paradox
content: Why induce AND inhibit the same enzyme? Coffee induces CYP1A2 (2-3x more enzyme). Nutmeg then inhibits it. Naive logic says they cancel out. Reality: More enzyme = more targets for inhibition = BIGGER accumulation when blocked. Analogy: Building more highway lanes right before blocking them all creates a worse traffic jam. The larger the system, the greater the backup when blocked.

title: Coffee Role in Oilahuasca - CYP1A2 Inducer
content: Coffee is a known inducer of CYP1A2 enzyme activity. Regular coffee drinkers have 2-3x more CYP1A2 than non-drinkers. Mechanism: Coffee compounds activate nuclear receptors (AhR, PXR) which increase CYP1A2 gene transcription. Time course: Peak induction at 24-72 hours with regular consumption. Caffeine itself is metabolized 95% by CYP1A2. Optimal dosing: 2-4 cups strong coffee for 3-7 days before, or 30-60 min before allylbenzenes.

title: Nutmeg - Central Compound of Oilahuasca
content: Nutmeg contains myristicin (1-3%), elemicin, and safrole. It is BOTH substrate AND inhibitor - the keystone of oilahuasca. Myristicin is the most potent CYP1A2 inhibitor among CYP1A2, CYP2D6, CYP2E1, CYP3A4, and CYP2C19 tested. Also has MAO inhibitory properties (Truitt 1963). Dual nature: acute mechanism-based inhibitor + chronic inducer. Psychoactive threshold: 2-5g. Toxic at 10g+. Duration: 24-72 hours.

title: Cinnamon Multiple CYP450 Inhibitor
content: Cinnamon contains cinnamaldehyde, eugenol, and trace safrole. It inhibits multiple CYP450 enzymes: CYP2C9, CYP3A4, CYP2A6, and CYP1A2. Critical additional effect: causes GLUTATHIONE DEPLETION, blocking Phase II detoxification. Role in oilahuasca: blocks alternative metabolic pathways + prevents Phase II conjugation. This is why cinnamon is essential - it closes the 'escape routes' when CYP1A2 is blocked.

title: Black Pepper Piperine CYP3A4 Inhibitor
content: Black pepper contains 5-10% piperine, a selective CYP3A4 inhibitor. CYP3A4 is the most prevalent liver CYP enzyme, handling >50% of all drugs. Piperine also inhibits P-glycoprotein (intestinal efflux transporter), increasing absorption. Famous example: piperine increases curcumin bioavailability by 2000%. Role in oilahuasca: blocks the CYP3A4 backup pathway. Dosing: 500mg-1g pepper (25-100mg piperine) or 20-50mg piperine extract.

title: Basil Triple Action in Oilahuasca
content: Basil provides three mechanisms: 1) Allylbenzene source (estragole 70-85% of oil, methyleugenol 3-10%), 2) SULT inhibition via nevadensin flavonoid, 3) Palatable flavoring. Nevadensin inhibits sulfotransferase (Phase II enzyme), blocking sulfate conjugation of metabolites. This means one herb provides both the 'drug' (estragole) and the 'potentiator' (nevadensin). Dosing: 2-4 tablespoons fresh chopped or 1-2 teaspoons dried.

title: Fennel Dual Action Herb
content: Fennel contains anethole (80-90%) and estragole (5-10%). CRITICAL: Anethole is PROPENYLBENZENE (conjugated double bond) - does NOT form psychoactive metabolites. Only the estragole (ALLYLBENZENE) is active. Fennel also contains mechanism-based CYP3A4 inhibitors. Connection to absinthe: anethole was the natural flavoring, may have contributed to 'altered state beyond alcohol'. Role in oilahuasca: provides estragole + blocks CYP3A4 backup pathway.

title: Allylbenzene vs Propenylbenzene Critical Distinction
content: Only ALLYLBENZENES form psychoactive metabolites. Allylbenzene structure: Benzene-CH2-CH=CH2 (oxidizable at benzylic carbon). Propenylbenzene structure: Benzene-CH=CH-CH3 (conjugated double bond BLOCKS oxidation). Psychoactive (allyl): myristicin, safrole, estragole, elemicin, apiole, dillapiole, methyleugenol. NOT psychoactive (propenyl): anethole, asarone, isosafrole, isoeugenol. This is why fennel's 80-90% anethole doesn't contribute.

title: Nutmeg Psychoactive Effects Verified
content: Nutmeg psychoactive effects dose-response: 0.5-1g (culinary) no effects, 1-2g mild stimulation, 2-5g clear psychoactive effects with visual distortions and altered time perception, 5-10g strong hallucinations but severe side effects, 10g+ toxic requiring medical attention. Duration extremely long: onset 2-8 hours, peak 6-12 hours, duration 24-72 hours, residual effects can persist a week. Character: dream-like, dissociative - NOT like classic psychedelics.

title: MAO Inhibition by Myristicin
content: Truitt et al. (1963) demonstrated nutmeg and myristicin show evidence of central MAO inhibition: lowered convulsive dose of tryptamine in mice (MAO normally breaks down tryptamine), increased rat brain serotonin concentrations (MAO normally breaks down serotonin). This adds a SECOND mechanism beyond CYP450 modulation. If MAO is inhibited, endogenous monoamines accumulate, potentially enhancing psychoactive effects.

title: Oilahuasca Safety and Toxicity Warnings
content: SERIOUS SAFETY CONCERNS: Nutmeg toxic at 10g+ (nausea, tachycardia, convulsions possible). Effects last 24-72 hours. Safrole, estragole, methyleugenol are hepatotoxic and potentially carcinogenic with chronic use (safrole restricted by FDA, betel is IARC Group I carcinogen). CYP inhibition affects prescription drug metabolism - dangerous interactions with statins, blood pressure meds, benzodiazepines. NO controlled human studies on combinations exist.

title: Oilahuasca Harm Reduction Guidelines
content: Harm reduction if exploring (NOT a recommendation): Start with VERY LOW doses. Never use alone - have a sitter. Plan for 24-72 hour duration. AVOID if on prescription medications. Do NOT use chronically (carcinogenicity concerns). Stay hydrated. Do not drive for 3 days. Know emergency resources. No antidote exists - only supportive care for nutmeg toxicity. Individual variation in CYP450 activity means unpredictable responses.

title: Original Anecdotal Oilahuasca Formula
content: The original anecdotal formula: Coffee + Almond + Cinnamon + Vanilla + Nutmeg. Component roles: Coffee provides CYP1A2 induction, Nutmeg provides myristicin (psychoactive) + CYP1A2 inhibition, Cinnamon provides multiple CYP inhibition + glutathione depletion, Vanilla provides metabolic modulation, Almond provides benzaldehyde (minor contribution). Key insight: not just nutmeg's direct effects, but enzyme-mediated potentiation analogous to ayahuasca.

title: Betel Safrole Source
content: Betel (Piper betle) flowers contain 15 mg/g safrole - significant source. Also contains unique chavibetol (3-hydroxy-4-methoxyallylbenzene). Traditional betel chewing practiced by 600 million people. Betel enhances CYP450 metabolic activity (inducer like coffee). CAUTION: Betel quid is IARC Group I carcinogen with long-term use. Safrole-DNA adducts documented. Use betel LEAF only (not areca nut), small amounts, not chronically.

title: Parsley and Dill Highly Potent Sources
content: Parsley seed contains apiole, which metabolizes toward DMMDA pathway - considered highly potent by Shulgin. Dill seed contains dillapiole, which metabolizes toward DMMDA-2 pathway - also highly potent. Both also contain myristicin. Apiole is a CYP1A2 inhibitor like myristicin. Note: Parsley and dill SEED oils are much more concentrated than leaves/weed. These represent the more potent end of the oilahuasca spectrum.

title: Phase II Metabolism Blockade
content: Normal Phase II metabolism conjugates compounds with glutathione (GST) or sulfate (SULT) to make them water-soluble for excretion. Oilahuasca blocks both: Cinnamon depletes glutathione substrate (even if GST enzyme is present, no GSH to conjugate), Basil's nevadensin inhibits SULT enzyme. Result: DOUBLE BLOCKADE - metabolites cannot be formed quickly (Phase I blocked) AND cannot be excreted quickly (Phase II blocked) = maximum accumulation.

title: Research Citations for Oilahuasca
content: Key scientific citations: PMID 12523956 - CYP3A4 and CYP1A2 enzymes in myristicin oxidation. PMID 26091900 - Myristicin mechanism-based inhibition of CYP1A2, identifies reactive metabolites M1 and M2. PMID 8554622 - Myristicin induces rat hepatic CYP450 enzymes 2-20 fold. PMID 9245741 - Myristicin induces GST 4-14 fold in mice. Truitt 1963 - Evidence of MAO inhibition by myristicin and nutmeg.

content: The Oilahuasca research connects to Van Kush Family interests: The Shaivite Temple uses sacred plants including cannabis for consciousness exploration. The 75,000-year temple tradition includes knowledge of psychoactive plants. This research extends understanding of plant-based consciousness exploration to common culinary spices.
